description: From Middle English busines, busynes, businesse, bisynes, from Old English bisiġnes (“business, busyness”), equivalent to busy +‎ -ness. Doublet of busyness.

entries.meaning: Of, to, pertaining to or utilized for purposes of conducting trade, commerce, governance, advocacy or other professional purposes.
examples: Please do not use this phone for personal calls; it is a business phone.

entries.meaning: Professional, businesslike, having concern for good business practice.
Supporting business, conducive to the conduct of business.
(countable) A specific commercial enterprise or establishment.
examples: Synonyms: see Thesaurus:enterprise
I was left my father's business.

entries.meaning: (countable) A person's occupation, work, or trade.
examples: He is in the motor and insurance businesses.
I'm going to Las Vegas on business.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Commercial, industrial, or professional activity.
examples: He's such a poor cook, I can't believe he's still in business!
We do business all over the world.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The volume or amount of commercial trade.
examples: Business has been slow lately.
They did nearly a million dollars of business over the long weekend.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) One's dealings; patronage.
examples: I shall take my business elsewhere.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Private commercial interests taken collectively.
examples: This proposal will satisfy both business and labor.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The management of commercial enterprises, or the study of such management.
examples: I studied business at Harvard.

entries.meaning: (countable) A particular situation or activity.
examples: This UFO stuff is a mighty strange business.

entries.meaning: (countable) Any activity or objective needing to be dealt with; especially, one of a financial or legal matter.
examples: Our principal business here is to get drunk.
Let's get down to business.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Something involving one personally.
examples: That's none of your business.

entries.meaning: (uncountable, parliamentary procedure) Matters that come before a body for deliberation or action.
examples: If that concludes the announcements, we'll move on to new business.

entries.meaning: (travel, uncountable) Business class, the class of seating provided by airlines between first class and coach.
(acting) Action carried out with a prop or piece of clothing, usually away from the focus of the scene.
(countable, rare) The collective noun for a group of ferrets.
(slang, Britain) Something very good; top quality. (possibly from "the bee's knees")
examples: These new phones are the business!

entries.meaning: (slang, uncountable) The act of defecation, or the excrement itself, particularly that of a non-human animal.
examples: Your ferret left his business all over the floor.
As the cart went by, its horse lifted its tail and did its business.

entries.meaning: (slang) Disruptive shenanigans.
examples: I haven't seen cartoons giving someone the business since the 1990s.

entries.meaning: (Australian Aboriginal) matters (e.g sorry business = a funeral)
